description: A simple standard bar chart that can handle both negative and positive magnitude values
name: Diverging bar

description: Perfect for presenting survey results which involve sentiment (eg disagree, neutral, agreed
name: Diverging stacked bar

description: Splits a single value into 2 contrasting components (eg Male/Female)
name: Spine

description: The shaded area of these charts allows a balance to be shown; either against a baseline or between two serie
name: Surplus/deficit filled line

description: Same as before.
name: Surplus/deficit filled area

description: The standard way to show the relationship between two variables, each of which has its own axis
name: Scatterplot

description: A good way of showing the relationship over time between an amount (columns) and a rate (line)
name: Column + line timeline

description: Usually used to show how the relationship between 2 variables has changed over time
name: Connected scatterplot

description: Like a scatterplot, but adds additional detail by sizing the circles according to a third variable
name: Bubble

description: A good way of showing the patterns between 2 categories of data, less good at showing fine differences in amounts
name: X Y Heatmap

description: Standard bar charts display the ranks of values much more easily when sorted into order
name: Ordered bar

description: See before
name: Ordered column

description: Use when there are big variations between values and/or seeing fine differences between data is not so important.
name: Ordered proportional symbol

description: Dots placed in order on a strip are a space-efficient method of laying out ranks across multiple categories.
name: Dot strip plot

description: Perfect for showing how ranks have changed over time or vary between categories.
name: Slope

description: Lollipop charts draw more attention to the data value than standard bar/column and can also show rank effectively
name: Lollipop

description: Effective for showing changing rankings across multiple dates. For large datasets, consider grouping lines using colour.
name: Bump

description: The standard way to show a statistical distribution - keep the gaps between columns small to highlight the 'shape' of the data.
name: Histogram

description: A simple way of showing the range (min/max) of data across multiple categories.
name: Dot plot

description: Good for showing individual values in a distribution, can be a problem when too many dots have the same value
name: Dot strip plot

description: Like dot strip plots, good for displaying all the data in a table,they work best when highlighting individual values.
name: Barcode plot

description: Summarise multiple distributions by showing the median (centre) and range of the data
name: Boxplot

description: Similar to a box plot but more effective with complex distributions (data that cannot be summarised with simple average).
name: Violin plot

description: A standard way for showing the age and sex breakdown of a population distribution; effectively, back to back histograms
name: Population pyramid

description: A good way of showing how unequal a distribution is: y axis is always cumulative frequency, x axis is always a measure.
name: Cumulative curve

description: For displaying multiple distributions of data. Like a regular line chart, best limited to a maximum of 3 or 4 datasets
name: Frequency polygons

description: The standard way to show a changing time series. If data are irregular, consider markers to represent data points
name: Line

description: Columns work well for showing change over time - but usually best with only one series of data at a time
name: Column

description: A good way of showing the relationship over time between an amount (columns) and a rate (line)
name: Column + line timeline

description: Good for showing changing data as long as the data can be simplified into 2 or 3 points without missing a key part of story
name: Slope

description: Use with care. These are good at showing changes to total, but seeing change in components can be very difficult.
name: Area chart

description: Usually focused on day-to-day activity, these charts show opening/closing and hi/low points of each day
name: Candlestick

description: Use to show the uncertainty in future projections - usually this grows the further forward to projection
name: Fan chart (projections)

description: A good way of showing changing data for two variables whenever there is a relatively clear pattern of progression.
name: Connected scatterplot

description: A great way of showing temporal patterns (daily, weekly, monthly), at the expense of showing precision in quantity
name: Calendar heatmap

description: Great when date and duration are key elements of the story in the data
name: Priestley timeline

description: Good for showing discrete values of varying size across multiple categories (eg earthquakes by contintent)
name: Circle timeline

description: Presents time on the Y axis. Good for displaying detailed time series that work especially well when scrolling on mobile
name: Vertical timeline

description: Another alternative to the circle timeline for showing series where there are big variations in the data
name: Seismogram

description: A type of area chart; use when seeing changes in proportions over time is more important than individual values
name: Streamgraph

description: The standard way to compare the size of things. Must always start at 0 on the axis
name: Column

description: See before. Good when the data are not time series and labels have long category names.
name: Bar

description: As per standard column but allows for multiple series. Can become tricky to read with more than 2 series
name: Paired column

description: As per standard bar but allows for multiple series. Can become tricky to read with more than 2 series
name: Paired bar

description: A good way of showing the size and proportion of data at the same time - as long as the data are not too complicated
name: Marimekko

description: Use when there are big variations between values and/or seeing fine dierences between data is not so important
name: Proportional symbol

description: Excellent solution in some instances - use only with whole numbers (do not slice off an arm to represent a decimal).
name: Isotype (pictogram)

description: Lollipop charts draw more attention to the data value than standard bar/column and can also show rank effectively
name: Lollipop

description: A space-efficient way of showing value pf multiple variables -  but make sure they are organised in a way that makes sense to reader.
name: Radar

description: An alternative to radar charts - again, the arrngement of the variables is important. Usually benefits from highlighting values
name: Parallel coordinates

description: Good for showing a measurement against the context of a target or performance range
name: Bullet

description: An alternative to bar/column charts when being able to count data or highlight individual elements is useful.
name: Grouped symbol

description: A simple way of showing part-to-whole relationships but can be difficult to read with more than a few components
name: Stacked column

description: A good way of showing the size and proportion of data at the same time as long as the data are not too complicated.
name: Marimekko

description: A common way of showing part-to-whole data - but be aware that it's difficult to accurately compare the size of the segments.
name: Pie

description: Similar to a pie chart - but the centre can be a good way of making space to include more information about the data (eg. total)
name: Donut

description: Use for hierarchical part-to-whole relationships; can be difficult to read when there are many small segments
name: Treemap

description: A way of turning points into areas - any point within the area is closer to the central point than any other point
name: Voronoi

description: A hemicycle, often used for visualising political results.
name: Arc

description: Good for showing % information, they work best when used on whole numbers and work well in multiple layout form.
name: Gridplot

description: Generally only used for schematic representation
name: Venn

description: Can be useful for showing part-to-whole relationships where some of the components are negative.
name: Waterfall

description: The standard approach for putting data on a map - should always be rates rather than totals and use a sensible base geography.
name: Basic choropleth (rate/ratio)

description: Use for totals rather than rates  - be wary that small differences in data will be hard to see.
name: Proportional symbol (count/magnitude)

description: For showing unambiguous movement across a map
name: Flow map

description: For showing areas of equal value on a map. Can use deviation colour schemes for showing +/- values
name: Contour map

description: Converting each unit on a map to a regular and equally-sized shape - good for representing voting regions with equal share.
name: Equalised cartogram

description: Stretching and shrinking a map so that each area is sized according to a particular value.
name: Scaled cartogram (value)

description: Used to show the location of individual events/locations - make sure to annotate any patterns the reader should see.
name: Dot density

description: Grid-based data values mapped with an intensity colour scale. As choropleth map - but not snapped to an admin/political unit.
name: Heat map

description: Shows changes in flows from one condition to at least one other; good for tracing the eventual outcome of a complex process.
name: Sankey

description: Designed to show the sequencing of data through a flow process, typically budgets. Can include +/- components
name: Waterfall

description: A complex but powerful diagram which can illustrate 2-way flows (and net winner) in a matrix
name: Chord

description: Used for showing the complexity and inter-connectdness of relationships of varying types.
name: Network
